page.title: 01OVERVIEW-THE LAND,SOUTH FEN
page.content: Two very small hamlets are found in this area known as South Fen, Twenty to the extreme north-east and Tongue End to the extreme south-east. The two hamlets are separated by the rivers Bourne Eau and Glen. The major part of Tongue End itself is outside the survey area and even with the addition of the few scattered farm houses the total population is less than seventy inhabitants. The land within the area is flat, rich,black reclaimed fenland lying between two and three metres above sea level. The land is protected from flooding by the highly-banked river Bourne Eau, which flows through the area from west to east, and a modern, sophisticated drainage system managed by the Black Sluice Board to the north and the Welland and Deepings Drainage Board to the south of the river.
